TopicTitle: The Venturer Program: Tour of the planets

Articles.Content:
Welp, my mouse packed in last night. It had been going for a little while; the RMB has lost its click and requires only the slightest nudge to right click. It was most problematic in KSP when trying to right click a fuel tank, often producing no response. In fact, last night, the button was permanently depressed, requiring that I actually hold up the button to stop it from doing anything, which, as you can imagine, was a pain in the a$$, rendering it unuseable. It was at the replacement point, so I made one last ditch effort to fix it, but alas, it just got worse. I'm posting this from my Kindle Fire, for the record.

Why am I posting this? Because I didn't post a chapter yesterday or today, and I'll be out of action until tomorrow, so you're all going to have to wait just a little longer

And here I was hoping to play more First Contract

But don't despair, it's only one day... I'm saying that to myself as much as I am to you, audience

Good chapter. Sorry to hear about the mouse; most annoying piece of equipment to break.

Also, I feel you have achieved the status of Master Reference- I AM ASSUMING DIRECT CONTROL.

CHAPTER 31: THE LONG WAIT Ã¢â‚¬â€œ PART 2

Many months later...

Captain's log, Libra, entry 14: We're closing in on Duna, at last. We entered the SOI a few hours ago and the planet is looking pretty big now. It's a shame we won't be landing there, but we can still admire it from way up here.

The Spacedock knows we're getting close, so at least we won't be waiting around for too long to dock there. We just need to get through the aerobrake and then we're home free.

-----

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, 2 minutes from atmospheric entry, buckle up folks.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I don't like this.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Don't like what?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Aerobraking. I don't trust it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Why?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I genuinely don't know.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Enford: Ã¢â‚¬Å“As long as you don't jinx it by saying things like this, I'll be happy.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, I'd rather not burn up in an alien sky, either.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I doubt very much we'll be facing problems like that. 1 minute.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'll raise the alarm bells if things start going wrong.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm sure you will.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, here we go. Duna isn't too bad for aerobraking, so this should be relatively calm.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I hope so.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few minutes later...

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Now that wasn't so bad, was it? Enford, get on the horn to the station, let them know we've done the aerobrake.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Enford: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm on it, Captain.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, so we're alive and the ship's fine. I really don't know why I was worried.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Nor do I. I take it the engines are good to go?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, they're all set.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Enford: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey, uh, Captain? You might want to hear this.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What is it?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Enford: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Here, I'll put you on.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, ok. Duna Spacedock, this is Wehrke of the Libra, what's up?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Wehrke, this is Matt. Listen, your mission is, uh... changing slightly.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, is that so? Let's hear it, then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few hours later...

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Libra, you're all clear to dock.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Understood. Ned?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“RCS thrusters are good to go.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good. Hey, uh, Matt? Have you told Enterprise about this?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“They know.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Plain and simple? So who's going to be in charge of the station?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm leaving that for the guys here to decide.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's fair enough, I guess. Ok, we're docking now, watch out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Clean connection. Pressure's are equalising now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then, let's get ready to welcome our guests.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Enford: Ã¢â‚¬Å“As long as they don't mess up my bunk...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Or mine.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey folks.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hello there. I take it you're Matt?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Aye, that would be me. Jerrick, Alan, bring Matton through, would you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jerrick: Ã¢â‚¬Å“On it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Alan: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Watch your head.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Is this the Libra?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jerrick: Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is it, buddy.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Huh, this hab looks a lot like the one on Enterprise, just cleaner.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Is that so?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah. At least I know it's gonna be comfy.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Are you sure this is what you want to do?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It's not like I really have much choice in the matter, is it? I'm too badly injured to carry on with the mission, unlike you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I take it this is our ride, Matt?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, this is it. Listen, Matton, you are recovering, so if you do want to carry on--Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I don't think I'd be of much use, now. Just promise me one thing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Don't get hurt. The guys on Enterprise don't need any more of that.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, it wasn't on my agenda to go jumping off a cliff anyway, but I'll try, buddy.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks. And Franklin?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Make sure you get a shot at piloting something.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I intend to.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good, then let's go.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jerrick, Alan, it's been good working with you guys. Tell that to the others, too.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jerrick: Ã¢â‚¬Å“The honour was ours, Matt. Thank you, and good luck out there.Ã¢â‚¬Â

The hatch seals behind them.

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Are you guys all set?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm ready whenever.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“As am I.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Let's roll.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You got it. Enford, undock us and I'll get us to Enterprise.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Aye, Captain.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few hours later...

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Libra to Enterprise, do you copy?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Libra, good to see you. Dock at port 4 and we'll meet you there.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Understood.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Last chance, Matton.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I stand resolute with my choice. Of course I'd love to carry on, but I just can't. I've got family to think about, too.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I understand.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“There is one thing, though. Get Lengas for me once we're docked.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Sure thing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We're aligned, moving in.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“IEV Libra has docked successfully. Equalising pressure now... complete.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That is one frakking big ship.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Enford: Ã¢â‚¬Å“And I thought Libra was a decently sized vessel.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Ned: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, we are decently sized, but Enterprise... Kod, what I wouldn't give to work aboard that beauty.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hey there, folks, welcome to Enterprise. Matton, good to see you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Likewise, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Matt, Franklin, I guess you can come aboard.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Franklin: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thank you, Captain.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Matton, I'll be right back with Lengas, alright?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Lengas?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“There's something on Enterprise that I really want, save for my belongings.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We'll have those brought through to you. Jim, Cal, get Matton's stuff, if you would.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You know, we still have room for you on board, Matton.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I know, but I'm not really in the best way, and like I just said to Matt, I've got family back home who were besides themselves with grief when they'd heard what happened. I just want to go home.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, if that's what you really want...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It is.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It's been great having you with us. I'll make sure to bring back more space rocks for you, from each of the places we've got left.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thank you Jeb, it's been a privilege to fly with you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Matton!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matt: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I told you I'd be quick.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks Matt.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn it, man, you gave me a real good scare a few months back.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh believe me, it was scary.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, at least you're ok. And that's the main thing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes, yes, but there is something I want that I believe is here.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That star-shaped rock I picked up from Duna. I want to study it on the way home.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'll go one better; I'll get that and a few other samples for you to play with.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Here's your stuff, Matton. Sorry you couldn't come with us.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, that's a downer.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks guys. Don't have too much fun without me, alright?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jim: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, definitely no promises on that one.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Maton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hah, alright then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks, you two.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Cal: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No problem, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, here you go. The star rock is in the little plastic case, there.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah, excellent. Thank you Lengas.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You're more than welcome.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You are ok, right?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I will be. At least I know Matt, and he's a good geologist, just like you.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good, good. Hey, I'll see you back on Kerbin.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That you will. Until then, buddy.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Until then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You know, Matton, I think you may have just saved us all.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Huh?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Lengas. He was moping around and making the ship quite a sombre place at times because of what happened. First Sid, then you? It drove him mad, and as a result, us too. I think seeing you alive and well may have just cheered him up enough to keep us all sane.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Well, if that's so, I'm glad I could help out.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Indeed. Well, we've got stuff to do, as I'm sure you know, so I'd best get going. Stay safe, Matton.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You too, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb floats back through the hatch and seals it behind him.

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Are we all good?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Matton: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, I'm ready to go.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Wehrke: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then. Enford, let's go.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Enford: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yes sir.Ã¢â‚¬Â
I've been reading your stories and they're great. Does your universe use in-situ resource mining like, say, Kethane? Those poor kerbals having to wait years for supply tankers...

You ask a Kerbal in my universe what Kethane is and they'll just give you a blank stare, maybe scratch their head a little and shrug before walking off. Maybe they'll even joke about you and your wonder gas over a pint later on in the evening. Of course, glorious fuel tankers are the only way forward for our supreme society!

...Put simply, I don't have Kethane installed

CHAPTER 32: DRES

Many months later...

Captain's log, entry 19: FINALLY, THE DRES TRANSFER. WE'VE BEEN WAITING FOR MONTHS NOW AND IT'S FINALLY HERE oh Kod, caps lock. Oops.

Anyway, the Dres window. Today we finally head off to that biggest of the lumps of rock in the asteroid belt. It's been a tough time waiting for this; we're all getting bored. I myself have managed to plough through most of the good films and books stored on the ships library, and having very little work to do in the mean time isn't helping. Lengas and Matt have at least been able to study their rocks, Mac's tending to Buzz, and Ed's maintaining the greenhouses. I try to help him out with that, sometimes, and he seems appreciative. He's a good person, Ed; quiet, calm, reserved. I'd say he's probably the least bored of us all simply because of his nature. At least someone's alright.

Lengas is still feeling down about Matton, and Mac is seriously considering prescribing him antidepressants despite the dwindling stock resulting from Buzz, who is now, remarkably, almost Buzz again. For the most part, he's acting like the man I know, although occasionally he does break into a gibbering mess while he's sleeping. Still, it's all progress, and I can only hope Lengas will follow suit. He's doing his job, though, and the ship is holding together. We've all been noticing some little faults here and there, and Lengas has been all over the place fixing them up. He also solved an issue with the fusion core in the engine, but told me to keep it to myself in case something bad happens, just so the crew don't panic. I reckon that he'll be back to normal soon enough.

Dean and Mac did have another argument, though, although I don't know what it was about. Buzz broke them up before I even had the chance to figure the thing out. Seriously, what is wrong with those two?

Ok, the Dres burn is coming up in a few hours, so I'd best make sure everything is ready to go.

-----

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“T-minus 5... 4... 3... 2.. 1... commence burn.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Firing up now, here we go!Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah good, the engine isn't exploding. We're at full throttle and fuel consumption is normal. Hull integrity standing at 96.8%Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hold on, why would the engine be exploding?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“There was a magnetic imbalance with the containment system. I fixed it, but I was scared that it might cause problems down the line.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Good Kod, if that had gone wrong...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We'd likely have been vapourised.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, thanks for fixing that, by the way, Lengas.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No problem, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I'm sure there are failsafes that stop the fusion core from exploding, right?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, but you don't leave things like that alone.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“True... right, we're halfway done.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Got it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“A fusion core explosion... not the worst way to go, I guess. No pain, just... gone.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Can we please not talk about it? I was petrified something would go awry, so I only told Jeb and made sure he kept it to himself to avoid everyone panicking.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's it, that's the first burn complete.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“My calculations point to a Dres encounter with 97% certainty. I do believe we'll make it there safely and with enough fuel to reach the fuel tanker around Jool.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Excellent. Now, I suppose that seeing as we haven't exploded, we can tell the rest of the crew about the core, Lengas.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Honestly, I'd rather not. I don't want to be responsible for making everyone fear for the lives, which could affect the mission. Besides, I've fixed it, it would seem. There's no need to go scaremongering.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“If that's what you want, then so be it. My lips are sealed.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Bill, Bob, same applies to you; do not say a word.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Understood.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bob: Ã¢â‚¬Å“You got it, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright, now then... Lengas, you still--Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Jeb, look, I know you want to beat me at Skrabble, but I'm really not feeling up for it. I'm sorry, but you're just going to have to wait.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It could help get you back on track.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I appreciate the sentiment, but I want to get back on track my own way, and that involves working.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alright then, just don't work too hard.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No promises.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Lengas floats back through to the hab.

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Of course, he could just be saying that so that he doesn't have to give up his Skrabble championship title.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It is a possibility.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“What he said is probably true, though. We both know that Lengas feels better when he feels like he's helping out, so...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, I know. I've got no problems with him, but he has to come up for air at some point.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Don't we all?Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few weeks later...

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Dres encounter confirmed, Captain.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Brilliant. Guys, we're going to Dres.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's good. I never got to land there the last time I visited.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Of course, you flew there with Venturer. That must have been an experience.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It was certainly interesting, despite being stuck in low orbit. It's just a shame I'll not be able to see those ravines up close, what with the mission objectives being the way they are.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“No, but it'll still be a good time down there; Dres is mostly unexplored. Only the ravines are really known territory.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yeah, that's true. Don't get me wrong, I don't mind where I'm landing, it looks to be a decent site, and walking on an alien planet is always a good thing.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Indeed.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“There's just one thing, Jeb; Sid was supposed to accompany Dean and I down there. Who's replacing him?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, right, err... I'll get in contact with control, see what they say about it, so hang tight.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Thanks, Jeb.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, and Buzz?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Hmm?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It's good to see you almost normal, again.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Buzz: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh believe me, it feels good to be almost normal. Anyway, I'll be back in the centrifuge if you need me.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Several months later...

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Alert: We have entered Dres' SOI.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“We have? Great. Bill, get over here, we need to make adjustments.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“One moment.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“This is an interesting moment for me. The Venturer mission to Dres was my first in active service, and now I'm back here. It will be interesting to see if anything has altered since the last time I was present.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ah yes, that's right, Stanley. Is that some natural curiosity that I'm detecting from you?Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I am an AI, Captain, I am made to think this way.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Of course you are.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Right, trajectory changes, let's see...Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I don't think it needs to be anything drastic this time round, fortunately.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“That's not by chance, I made sure it was so.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Oh, alright then, Mr. Perfect.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Mr. Perfect wouldn't need to make corrections right now.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I retract my compliment, then.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Aw, I didn't know it was a compliment.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Yep, and now you lost it.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Damn.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“However, I will give you Mr. Perfectionist.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“I suppose that'll do. Uh, we may have a problem.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“How so?Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Any corrections we make are going to be too delta-V intensive for my liking.Ã¢â‚¬Â

ANSI/Stanley: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Analysing... confirmed, any manoeuvres aside from the deceleration burn will put us into the yellow for fuel levels upon arriving at Jool.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Ok then, we'll just sort everything out once we're in orbit, not to worry.Ã¢â‚¬Â

Bill: Ã¢â‚¬Å“It'll have to do.Ã¢â‚¬Â

A few hours later...

Jeb: Ã¢â‚¬Å“Disengaging throttle. Bill, are we looking good or what?Ã¢â‚¬Â

CHAPTER 37: SWIRLING GREEN GLOBE

Captain's log, entry 20: Well, Mac hates me. I gave him the verdict, and before he could yell at me I give him the footage as well so he could review it. While he did reach the same conclusion, he was not happy in the slightest. I'm going to avoid him for a little bit.

Anyway, we're now waiting for the Jool transfer window. We've got months ahead of us with very little to do, so I'm going to let Dean go ahead with his zero-g catch idea. It sounds fun, so I'll probably join in from time to time, provided we aren't throwing wrenches around, because one, Lengas would kill us, and two, if that thing hit anyone in their suit, they'd be in big trouble. Speaking of Lengas, he does look to be getting back to normal. He's talking more, which is always a good sign, and he's been slowing down on the anti-depressants, I'm told. I knew he'd get there eventually, but I do completely sympathise with him and the situation he's faced. I may pull out the Skrabble board again, ask him if he's up for giving my championship title back to me.

Oh, and before I forget it, Matton contacted us from the Libra. He says they just left Duna for Kerbin , and that was... what, 3 hours ago? Yeah, 3 hours. He's also recovering quite well, according to Wehrke, the captain over there. I told Lengas and it cheered him up a bit more. That's always good stuff to see. If Matton had died as well as Sid... I don't think it would be entirely bearable here.

-----
